20 #ifdef _MAKEDOC

27 #include "buffy.h"

29 #ifndef _MAKEDOC
30 #define DT_MASK 0x0f
31 #define DT_BOOL 1 /* boolean option */
32 #define DT_NUM 2 /* a number */
33 #define DT_STR 3 /* a string */
34 #define DT_PATH 4 /* a pathname */
35 #define DT_QUAD 5 /* quad-option (yes/no/ask-yes/ask-no) */
36 #define DT_SORT 6 /* sorting methods */
37 #define DT_RX 7 /* regular expressions */
38 #define DT_MAGIC 8 /* mailbox type */
39 #define DT_SYN 9 /* synonym for another variable */
40 #define DT_ADDR 10 /* e-mail address */
41 #define DT_MBCHARTBL 11 /* multibyte char table */
42 #define DT_HCACHE 12 /* header cache backend */
43 
44 #define DTYPE(x) ((x) & DT_MASK)
45 
46 /* subtypes */
47 #define DT_SUBTYPE_MASK 0xff0
48 #define DT_SORT_ALIAS 0x10
49 #define DT_SORT_BROWSER 0x20
50 #define DT_SORT_KEYS 0x40
51 #define DT_SORT_AUX 0x80
52 #define DT_SORT_SIDEBAR 0x100
53 
54 /* flags to parse_set() */
55 #define MUTT_SET_INV (1<<0) /* default is to invert all vars */
56 #define MUTT_SET_UNSET (1<<1) /* default is to unset all vars */
57 #define MUTT_SET_RESET (1<<2) /* default is to reset all vars to default */
58 
59 /* forced redraw/resort types */
60 #define R_NONE 0
61 #define R_INDEX (1<<0)
62 #define R_PAGER (1<<1)
63 #define R_RESORT (1<<2) /* resort the mailbox */
64 #define R_RESORT_SUB (1<<3) /* resort subthreads */
65 #define R_RESORT_INIT (1<<4) /* resort from scratch */
66 #define R_TREE (1<<5) /* redraw the thread tree */
67 #define R_REFLOW (1<<6) /* reflow window layout */
68 #define R_SIDEBAR (1<<7) /* redraw the sidebar */
69 #define R_BOTH (R_INDEX | R_PAGER)
70 #define R_RESORT_BOTH (R_RESORT | R_RESORT_SUB)
71 
72 struct option_t
73 {
74  char *option;
75  short type;
76  short flags;
77  unsigned long data;
78  unsigned long init; /* initial value */
79 };
80 
81 #define UL (unsigned long)
82 
83 #endif /* _MAKEDOC */
84 
85 #ifndef ISPELL
86 #define ISPELL "ispell"
87 #endif

89 struct option_t MuttVars[] = {
90  /*++*/
91 
92  { "abort_noattach", DT_QUAD, R_NONE, OPT_ATTACH, MUTT_NO },
93  /*
94  ** .pp
95  ** If set to \fIyes\fP, when composing messages containing the regular expression
96  ** specified by $attach_keyword and no attachments ** are given, composition
97  ** will be aborted. If set to \fIno\fP, composing ** messages as such will never
98  ** be aborted.
99  ** .pp
100  ** Example:
101  ** .ts
102  ** set attach_keyword = "\<attach(|ed|ments?)\>"
103  ** .te
104  */
105  { "abort_nosubject", DT_QUAD, R_NONE, OPT_SUBJECT, MUTT_ASKYES },
106  /*
107  ** .pp
108  ** If set to \fIyes\fP, when composing messages and no subject is given
109  ** at the subject prompt, composition will be aborted. If set to
110  ** \fIno\fP, composing messages with no subject given at the subject
111  ** prompt will never be aborted.
112  */
113  { "abort_unmodified", DT_QUAD, R_NONE, OPT_ABORT, MUTT_YES },
114  /*
115  ** .pp
116  ** If set to \fIyes\fP, composition will automatically abort after
117  ** editing the message body if no changes are made to the file (this
118  ** check only happens after the \fIfirst\fP edit of the file). When set
119  ** to \fIno\fP, composition will never be aborted.
120  */
121  { "alias_file", DT_PATH, R_NONE, UL &AliasFile, UL "~/.muttrc" },
122  /*
123  ** .pp
124  ** The default file in which to save aliases created by the
125  ** \fC$<create-alias>\fP function. Entries added to this file are
126  ** encoded in the character set specified by $$config_charset if it
127  ** is \fIset\fP or the current character set otherwise.
128  ** .pp
129  ** \fBNote:\fP Mutt will not automatically source this file; you must
130  ** explicitly use the ``$source'' command for it to be executed in case
131  ** this option points to a dedicated alias file.
132  ** .pp
133  ** The default for this option is the currently used muttrc file, or
134  ** ``~/.muttrc'' if no user muttrc was found.
135  */
136  { "alias_format", DT_STR, R_NONE, UL &AliasFmt, UL "%4n %2f %t %-10a %r" },
137  /*
138  ** .pp
139  ** Specifies the format of the data displayed for the ``$alias'' menu. The
140  ** following \fCprintf(3)\fP-style sequences are available:
141  ** .dl
142  ** .dt %a .dd alias name
143  ** .dt %f .dd flags - currently, a ``d'' for an alias marked for deletion
144  ** .dt %n .dd index number
145  ** .dt %r .dd address which alias expands to
146  ** .dt %t .dd character which indicates if the alias is tagged for inclusion
147  ** .de
148  */
149  { "allow_8bit", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTALLOW8BIT, 1 },
150  /*
151  ** .pp
152  ** Controls whether 8-bit data is converted to 7-bit using either Quoted-
153  ** Printable or Base64 encoding when sending mail.
154  */
155  { "allow_ansi", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTALLOWANSI, 0 },
156  /*
157  ** .pp
158  ** Controls whether ANSI color codes in messages (and color tags in
159  ** rich text messages) are to be interpreted.
160  ** Messages containing these codes are rare, but if this option is \fIset\fP,
161  ** their text will be colored accordingly. Note that this may override
162  ** your color choices, and even present a security problem, since a
163  ** message could include a line like
164  ** .ts
165  ** [-- PGP output follows ...
166  ** .te
167  ** .pp
168  ** and give it the same color as your attachment color (see also
169  ** $$crypt_timestamp).
170  */
171  { "arrow_cursor", DT_BOOL, R_BOTH, OPTARROWCURSOR, 0 },
172  /*
173  ** .pp
174  ** When \fIset\fP, an arrow (``->'') will be used to indicate the current entry
175  ** in menus instead of highlighting the whole line. On slow network or modem
176  ** links this will make response faster because there is less that has to
177  ** be redrawn on the screen when moving to the next or previous entries
178  ** in the menu.
179  */
180  { "ascii_chars", DT_BOOL, R_BOTH, OPTASCIICHARS, 0 },
181  /*
182  ** .pp
183  ** If \fIset\fP, Mutt will use plain ASCII characters when displaying thread
184  ** and attachment trees, instead of the default \fIACS\fP characters.
185  */
186  { "askbcc", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTASKBCC, 0 },
187  /*
188  ** .pp
189  ** If \fIset\fP, Mutt will prompt you for blind-carbon-copy (Bcc) recipients
190  ** before editing an outgoing message.
191  */
192  { "askcc", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTASKCC, 0 },
193  /*
194  ** .pp
195  ** If \fIset\fP, Mutt will prompt you for carbon-copy (Cc) recipients before
196  ** editing the body of an outgoing message.
197  */
198 #ifdef USE_NNTP
199  { "ask_follow_up", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTASKFOLLOWUP, 0 },
200  /*
201  ** .pp
202  ** If set, Mutt will prompt you for follow-up groups before editing
203  ** the body of an outgoing message.
204  */
205  { "ask_x_comment_to", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTASKXCOMMENTTO, 0 },
206  /*
207  ** .pp
208  ** If set, Mutt will prompt you for x-comment-to field before editing
209  ** the body of an outgoing message.
210  */
211 #endif
212  { "assumed_charset", DT_STR, R_NONE, UL &AssumedCharset, UL 0},
213  /*
214  ** .pp
215  ** This variable is a colon-separated list of character encoding
216  ** schemes for messages without character encoding indication.
217  ** Header field values and message body content without character encoding
218  ** indication would be assumed that they are written in one of this list.
219  ** By default, all the header fields and message body without any charset
220  ** indication are assumed to be in ``us-ascii''.
221  ** .pp
222  ** For example, Japanese users might prefer this:
223  ** .ts
224  ** set assumed_charset="iso-2022-jp:euc-jp:shift_jis:utf-8"
225  ** .te
226  ** .pp
227  ** However, only the first content is valid for the message body.
228  */
229  { "attach_charset", DT_STR, R_NONE, UL &AttachCharset, UL 0 },
230  /*
231  ** .pp
232  ** This variable is a colon-separated list of character encoding
233  ** schemes for text file attachments. Mutt uses this setting to guess
234  ** which encoding files being attached are encoded in to convert them to
235  ** a proper character set given in $$send_charset.
236  ** .pp
237  ** If \fIunset\fP, the value of $$charset will be used instead.
238  ** For example, the following configuration would work for Japanese
239  ** text handling:
240  ** .ts
241  ** set attach_charset="iso-2022-jp:euc-jp:shift_jis:utf-8"
242  ** .te
243  ** .pp
244  ** Note: for Japanese users, ``iso-2022-*'' must be put at the head
245  ** of the value as shown above if included.
246  */
247  { "attach_format", DT_STR, R_NONE, UL &AttachFormat, UL "%u%D%I %t%4n %T%.40d%> [%.7m/%.10M, %.6e%?C?, %C?, %s] " },
248  /*
249  ** .pp
250  ** This variable describes the format of the ``attachment'' menu. The
251  ** following \fCprintf(3)\fP-style sequences are understood:
252  ** .dl
253  ** .dt %C .dd charset
254  ** .dt %c .dd requires charset conversion (``n'' or ``c'')
255  ** .dt %D .dd deleted flag
256  ** .dt %d .dd description
257  ** .dt %e .dd MIME content-transfer-encoding
258  ** .dt %F .dd filename for content-disposition header
259  ** .dt %f .dd filename
260  ** .dt %I .dd disposition (``I'' for inline, ``A'' for attachment)
261  ** .dt %m .dd major MIME type
262  ** .dt %M .dd MIME subtype
263  ** .dt %n .dd attachment number
264  ** .dt %Q .dd ``Q'', if MIME part qualifies for attachment counting
265  ** .dt %s .dd size
266  ** .dt %t .dd tagged flag
267  ** .dt %T .dd graphic tree characters
268  ** .dt %u .dd unlink (=to delete) flag
269  ** .dt %X .dd number of qualifying MIME parts in this part and its children
270  ** (please see the ``$attachments'' section for possible speed effects)
271  ** .dt %>X .dd right justify the rest of the string and pad with character ``X''
272  ** .dt %|X .dd pad to the end of the line with character ``X''
273  ** .dt %*X .dd soft-fill with character ``X'' as pad
274  ** .de
275  ** .pp
276  ** For an explanation of ``soft-fill'', see the $$index_format documentation.
277  */
278  { "attach_keyword", DT_RX, R_NONE, UL &AttachKeyword, UL "\\<(attach|attached|attachments?)\\>" },
279  /*
280  ** .pp
281  ** If $abort_noattach is not set to no, then the body of the message
282  ** will be scanned for this regular expression, and if found, you will
283  ** be prompted if there are no attachments.
284  */
285  { "attach_sep", DT_STR, R_NONE, UL &AttachSep, UL "\n" },
286  /*
287  ** .pp
288  ** The separator to add between attachments when operating (saving,
289  ** printing, piping, etc) on a list of tagged attachments.
290  */
291  { "attach_split", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTATTACHSPLIT, 1 },
292  /*
293  ** .pp
294  ** If this variable is \fIunset\fP, when operating (saving, printing, piping,
295  ** etc) on a list of tagged attachments, Mutt will concatenate the
296  ** attachments and will operate on them as a single attachment. The
297  ** $$attach_sep separator is added after each attachment. When \fIset\fP,
298  ** Mutt will operate on the attachments one by one.
299  */
300  { "attribution", DT_STR, R_NONE, UL &Attribution, UL "On %d, %n wrote:" },
301  /*
302  ** .pp
303  ** This is the string that will precede a message which has been included
304  ** in a reply. For a full listing of defined \fCprintf(3)\fP-like sequences see
305  ** the section on $$index_format.
306  */
307  { "attribution_locale", DT_STR, R_NONE, UL &AttributionLocale, UL "" },
308  /*
309  ** .pp
310  ** The locale used by \fCstrftime(3)\fP to format dates in the
311  ** $attribution string. Legal values are the strings your system
312  ** accepts for the locale environment variable \fC$$$LC_TIME\fP.
313  ** .pp
314  ** This variable is to allow the attribution date format to be
315  ** customized by recipient or folder using hooks. By default, Mutt
316  ** will use your locale environment, so there is no need to set
317  ** this except to override that default.
318  */
319  { "auto_tag", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTAUTOTAG, 0 },
320  /*
321  ** .pp
322  ** When \fIset\fP, functions in the \fIindex\fP menu which affect a message
323  ** will be applied to all tagged messages (if there are any). When
324  ** unset, you must first use the \fC<tag-prefix>\fP function (bound to ``;''
325  ** by default) to make the next function apply to all tagged messages.
326  */
327  { "autoedit", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTAUTOEDIT, 0 },
328  /*
329  ** .pp
330  ** When \fIset\fP along with $$edit_headers, Mutt will skip the initial
331  ** send-menu (prompting for subject and recipients) and allow you to
332  ** immediately begin editing the body of your
333  ** message. The send-menu may still be accessed once you have finished
334  ** editing the body of your message.
335  ** .pp
336  ** .pp
337  ** \fBNote:\fP when this option is \fIset\fP, you cannot use send-hooks that depend
338  ** on the recipients when composing a new (non-reply) message, as the initial
339  ** list of recipients is empty.
340  ** .pp
341  ** Also see $$fast_reply.
342  */
343  { "beep", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTBEEP, 1 },
344  /*
345  ** .pp
346  ** When this variable is \fIset\fP, mutt will beep when an error occurs.
347  */
348  { "beep_new", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTBEEPNEW, 0 },
349  /*
350  ** .pp
351  ** When this variable is \fIset\fP, mutt will beep whenever it prints a message
352  ** notifying you of new mail. This is independent of the setting of the
353  ** $$beep variable.
354  */
355  { "bounce", DT_QUAD, R_NONE, OPT_BOUNCE, MUTT_ASKYES },
356  /*
357  ** .pp
358  ** Controls whether you will be asked to confirm bouncing messages.
359  ** If set to \fIyes\fP you don't get asked if you want to bounce a
360  ** message. Setting this variable to \fIno\fP is not generally useful,
361  ** and thus not recommended, because you are unable to bounce messages.
362  */
363  { "bounce_delivered", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTBOUNCEDELIVERED, 1 },
364  /*
365  ** .pp
366  ** When this variable is \fIset\fP, mutt will include Delivered-To headers when

369  { "braille_friendly", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTBRAILLEFRIENDLY, 0 },
370  /*
371  ** .pp
372  ** When this variable is \fIset\fP, mutt will place the cursor at the beginning
373  ** of the current line in menus, even when the $$arrow_cursor variable
374  ** is \fIunset\fP, making it easier for blind persons using Braille displays to
375  ** follow these menus. The option is \fIunset\fP by default because many
376  ** visual terminals don't permit making the cursor invisible.
377  */
378 #ifdef USE_NNTP
379  { "catchup_newsgroup", DT_QUAD, R_NONE, OPT_CATCHUP, MUTT_ASKYES },
380  /*
381  ** .pp
382  ** If this variable is \fIset\fP, Mutt will mark all articles in newsgroup
383  ** as read when you quit the newsgroup (catchup newsgroup).
384  */
385 #endif
386 #if defined(USE_SSL)
387  { "certificate_file", DT_PATH, R_NONE, UL &SslCertFile, UL "~/.mutt_certificates" },
388  /*
389  ** .pp
390  ** This variable specifies the file where the certificates you trust
391  ** are saved. When an unknown certificate is encountered, you are asked
392  ** if you accept it or not. If you accept it, the certificate can also
393  ** be saved in this file and further connections are automatically
394  ** accepted.
395  ** .pp
396  ** You can also manually add CA certificates in this file. Any server
397  ** certificate that is signed with one of these CA certificates is
398  ** also automatically accepted.
399  ** .pp
400  ** Example:
401  ** .ts
402  ** set certificate_file=~/.mutt/certificates
403  ** .te
404  **
405  */
406 #endif
407  { "charset", DT_STR, R_NONE, UL &Charset, UL 0 },
408  /*
409  ** .pp
410  ** Character set your terminal uses to display and enter textual data.
411  ** It is also the fallback for $$send_charset.
412  ** .pp
413  ** Upon startup Mutt tries to derive this value from environment variables
414  ** such as \fC$$$LC_CTYPE\fP or \fC$$$LANG\fP.
415  ** .pp
416  ** \fBNote:\fP It should only be set in case Mutt isn't able to determine the
417  ** character set used correctly.
418  */
419  { "check_mbox_size", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTCHECKMBOXSIZE, 0 },
420  /*
421  ** .pp
422  ** When this variable is \fIset\fP, mutt will use file size attribute instead of
423  ** access time when checking for new mail in mbox and mmdf folders.
424  ** .pp
425  ** This variable is \fIunset\fP by default and should only be enabled when
426  ** new mail detection for these folder types is unreliable or doesn't work.
427  ** .pp
428  ** Note that enabling this variable should happen before any ``$mailboxes''
429  ** directives occur in configuration files regarding mbox or mmdf folders
430  ** because mutt needs to determine the initial new mail status of such a
431  ** mailbox by performing a fast mailbox scan when it is defined.
432  ** Afterwards the new mail status is tracked by file size changes.
433  */
434  { "check_new", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTCHECKNEW, 1 },
435  /*
436  ** .pp
437  ** \fBNote:\fP this option only affects \fImaildir\fP and \fIMH\fP style
438  ** mailboxes.
439  ** .pp
440  ** When \fIset\fP, Mutt will check for new mail delivered while the
441  ** mailbox is open. Especially with MH mailboxes, this operation can
442  ** take quite some time since it involves scanning the directory and
443  ** checking each file to see if it has already been looked at. If
444  ** this variable is \fIunset\fP, no check for new mail is performed
445  ** while the mailbox is open.
446  */
447  { "collapse_unread", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTCOLLAPSEUNREAD, 1 },
448  /*
449  ** .pp
450  ** When \fIunset\fP, Mutt will not collapse a thread if it contains any
451  ** unread messages.
452  */
453  { "compose_format", DT_STR, R_BOTH, UL &ComposeFormat, UL "-- NeoMutt: Compose [Approx. msg size: %l Atts: %a]%>-" },
454  /*
455  ** .pp
456  ** Controls the format of the status line displayed in the ``compose''
457  ** menu. This string is similar to $$status_format, but has its own
458  ** set of \fCprintf(3)\fP-like sequences:
459  ** .dl
460  ** .dt %a .dd total number of attachments
461  ** .dt %h .dd local hostname
462  ** .dt %l .dd approximate size (in bytes) of the current message
463  ** .dt %v .dd Mutt version string
464  ** .de
465  ** .pp
466  ** See the text describing the $$status_format option for more
467  ** information on how to set $$compose_format.
468  */
469  { "config_charset", DT_STR, R_NONE, UL &ConfigCharset, UL 0 },
470  /*
471  ** .pp
472  ** When defined, Mutt will recode commands in rc files from this
473  ** encoding to the current character set as specified by $$charset
474  ** and aliases written to $$alias_file from the current character set.
475  ** .pp
476  ** Please note that if setting $$charset it must be done before
477  ** setting $$config_charset.
478  ** .pp
479  ** Recoding should be avoided as it may render unconvertable
480  ** characters as question marks which can lead to undesired
481  ** side effects (for example in regular expressions).
482  */
483  { "confirmappend", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTCONFIRMAPPEND, 1 },

491  ** .pp
492  ** When \fIset\fP, Mutt will prompt for confirmation when saving messages to a
493  ** mailbox which does not yet exist before creating it.
494  */
495  { "connect_timeout", DT_NUM, R_NONE, UL &ConnectTimeout, 30 },
496  /*
497  ** .pp
498  ** Causes Mutt to timeout a network connection (for IMAP, POP or SMTP) after this
499  ** many seconds if the connection is not able to be established. A negative
500  ** value causes Mutt to wait indefinitely for the connection attempt to succeed.
501  */
502  { "content_type", DT_STR, R_NONE, UL &ContentType, UL "text/plain" },
503  /*
504  ** .pp
505  ** Sets the default Content-Type for the body of newly composed messages.
506  */
507  { "copy", DT_QUAD, R_NONE, OPT_COPY, MUTT_YES },
508  /*
509  ** .pp
510  ** This variable controls whether or not copies of your outgoing messages
511  ** will be saved for later references. Also see $$record,
512  ** $$save_name, $$force_name and ``$fcc-hook''.
513  */
514  { "pgp_autoencrypt", DT_SYN, R_NONE, UL "crypt_autoencrypt", 0 },
515  { "crypt_autoencrypt", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTCRYPTAUTOENCRYPT, 0 },
516  /*
517  ** .pp
518  ** Setting this variable will cause Mutt to always attempt to PGP
519  ** encrypt outgoing messages. This is probably only useful in
520  ** connection to the ``$send-hook'' command. It can be overridden
521  ** by use of the pgp menu, when encryption is not required or
522  ** signing is requested as well. If $$smime_is_default is \fIset\fP,
523  ** then OpenSSL is used instead to create S/MIME messages and
524  ** settings can be overridden by use of the smime menu instead.
525  ** (Crypto only)
526  */
527  { "crypt_autopgp", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTCRYPTAUTOPGP, 1 },
528  /*
529  ** .pp
530  ** This variable controls whether or not mutt may automatically enable
531  ** PGP encryption/signing for messages. See also $$crypt_autoencrypt,
532  ** $$crypt_replyencrypt,
533  ** $$crypt_autosign, $$crypt_replysign and $$smime_is_default.
534  */
535  { "pgp_autosign", DT_SYN, R_NONE, UL "crypt_autosign", 0 },
536  { "crypt_autosign", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTCRYPTAUTOSIGN, 0 },
537  /*
538  ** .pp
539  ** Setting this variable will cause Mutt to always attempt to
540  ** cryptographically sign outgoing messages. This can be overridden
541  ** by use of the pgp menu, when signing is not required or
542  ** encryption is requested as well. If $$smime_is_default is \fIset\fP,
543  ** then OpenSSL is used instead to create S/MIME messages and settings can
544  ** be overridden by use of the smime menu instead of the pgp menu.
545  ** (Crypto only)
546  */
547  { "crypt_autosmime", DT_BOOL, R_NONE, OPTCRYPTAUTOSMIME, 1 },
548  /*
549  ** .pp
550  ** This variable controls whether or not mutt may automatically enable
551  ** S/MIME encryption/signing for messages. See also $$crypt_autoencrypt,
552  ** $$crypt_replyencrypt,

1434  ** the quoting mechanism is strictly defined for format=flowed.

1438  */
1439  { "indent_str", DT_SYN, R_NONE, UL "indent_string", 0 },
1440  /*
1441  */
1442  { "index_format", DT_STR, R_BOTH, UL &HdrFmt, UL "%4C %Z %{%b %d} %-15.15L (%?l?%4l&%4c?) %s" },
1443  /*
1444  ** .pp
1445  ** This variable allows you to customize the message index display to
1446  ** your personal taste.
1447  ** .pp
1448  ** ``Format strings'' are similar to the strings used in the C
1449  ** function \fCprintf(3)\fP to format output (see the man page for more details).
1450  ** The following sequences are defined in Mutt:
1451  ** .dl
1452  ** .dt %a .dd address of the author
1453  ** .dt %A .dd reply-to address (if present; otherwise: address of author)
1454  ** .dt %b .dd filename of the original message folder (think mailbox)
1455  ** .dt %B .dd the list to which the letter was sent, or else the folder name (%b).
1456  ** .dt %c .dd number of characters (bytes) in the message
1457  ** .dt %C .dd current message number
1458  ** .dt %d .dd date and time of the message in the format specified by
1459  ** $$date_format converted to sender's time zone
1460  ** .dt %D .dd date and time of the message in the format specified by
1461  ** $$date_format converted to the local time zone
1462  ** .dt %e .dd current message number in thread
1463  ** .dt %E .dd number of messages in current thread
1464  ** .dt %f .dd sender (address + real name), either From: or Return-Path:
1465  ** .dt %F .dd author name, or recipient name if the message is from you
1466  ** .dt %g .dd newsgroup name (if compiled with NNTP support)
1467  ** .dt %g .dd message labels (e.g. notmuch tags)
1468  ** .dt %H .dd spam attribute(s) of this message
1469  ** .dt %i .dd message-id of the current message
1470  ** .dt %l .dd number of lines in the message (does not work with maildir,
1471  ** mh, and possibly IMAP folders)
1472  ** .dt %L .dd If an address in the ``To:'' or ``Cc:'' header field matches an address
1473  ** defined by the users ``$subscribe'' command, this displays
1474  ** "To <list-name>", otherwise the same as %F.
1475  ** .dt %m .dd total number of message in the mailbox
1476  ** .dt %M .dd number of hidden messages if the thread is collapsed.
1477  ** .dt %N .dd message score
1478  ** .dt %n .dd author's real name (or address if missing)
1479  ** .dt %O .dd original save folder where mutt would formerly have
1480  ** stashed the message: list name or recipient name
1481  ** if not sent to a list
1482  ** .dt %P .dd progress indicator for the built-in pager (how much of the file has been displayed)
1483  ** .dt %r .dd comma separated list of ``To:'' recipients
1484  ** .dt %R .dd comma separated list of ``Cc:'' recipients
1485  ** .dt %s .dd subject of the message
1486  ** .dt %S .dd status of the message (``N''/``D''/``d''/``!''/``r''/\(as)
1487  ** .dt %t .dd ``To:'' field (recipients)
1488  ** .dt %T .dd the appropriate character from the $$to_chars string
1489  ** .dt %u .dd user (login) name of the author
1490  ** .dt %v .dd first name of the author, or the recipient if the message is from you
1491  ** .dt %W .dd name of organization of author (``Organization:'' field)
1492  ** .dt %x .dd ``X-Comment-To:'' field (if present and compiled with NNTP support)
1493  ** .dt %X .dd number of attachments
1494  ** (please see the ``$attachments'' section for possible speed effects)
1495  ** .dt %y .dd ``X-Label:'' field, if present
1496  ** .dt %Y .dd ``X-Label:'' field, if present, and \fI(1)\fP not at part of a thread tree,
1497  ** \fI(2)\fP at the top of a thread, or \fI(3)\fP ``X-Label:'' is different from
1498  ** preceding message's ``X-Label:''.
1499  ** .dt %Z .dd message status flags
1500  ** .dt %{fmt} .dd the date and time of the message is converted to sender's
1501  ** time zone, and ``fmt'' is expanded by the library function
1502  ** \fCstrftime(3)\fP; a leading bang disables locales
1503  ** .dt %[fmt] .dd the date and time of the message is converted to the local
1504  ** time zone, and ``fmt'' is expanded by the library function
1505  ** \fCstrftime(3)\fP; a leading bang disables locales
1506  ** .dt %(fmt) .dd the local date and time when the message was received.
1507  ** ``fmt'' is expanded by the library function \fCstrftime(3)\fP;
1508  ** a leading bang disables locales
1509  ** .dt %<fmt> .dd the current local time. ``fmt'' is expanded by the library
1510  ** function \fCstrftime(3)\fP; a leading bang disables locales.
1511  ** .dt %>X .dd right justify the rest of the string and pad with character ``X''
1512  ** .dt %|X .dd pad to the end of the line with character ``X''
1513  ** .dt %*X .dd soft-fill with character ``X'' as pad
1514  ** .de
1515  ** .pp
1516  ** Date format expressions can be constructed based on relative dates. Using
1517  ** the date formatting operators along with nested conditionals, the date
1518  ** format can be modified based on how old a message is. See the section on
1519  ** ``Conditional Dates'' for an explanation and examples
1520  ** ``Soft-fill'' deserves some explanation: Normal right-justification
1521  ** will print everything to the left of the ``%>'', displaying padding and
1522  ** whatever lies to the right only if there's room. By contrast,
1523  ** soft-fill gives priority to the right-hand side, guaranteeing space
1524  ** to display it and showing padding only if there's still room. If
1525  ** necessary, soft-fill will eat text leftwards to make room for
1526  ** rightward text.
1527  ** .pp
1528  ** Note that these expandos are supported in
1529  ** ``$save-hook'', ``$fcc-hook'' and ``$fcc-save-hook'', too.
1530  */
1531 #ifdef USE_NNTP
1532  { "inews", DT_PATH, R_NONE, UL &Inews, UL "" },
1533  /*
1534  ** .pp
1535  ** If set, specifies the program and arguments used to deliver news posted
1536  ** by Mutt. Otherwise, mutt posts article using current connection to
1537  ** news server. The following printf-style sequence is understood:
1538  ** .dl
1539  ** .dt %a .dd account url
1540  ** .dt %p .dd port
1541  ** .dt %P .dd port if specified
1542  ** .dt %s .dd news server name

3090  ** .de
3091  ** .pp

3093  ** process will be put in a temporary file. If there is some error, you
3094  ** will be informed as to where to find the output.
3095  */

3178  ** .dt %*X .dd soft-fill with character ``X'' as pad

3182  ** @ = Only applicable to the current folder
3183  ** .pp

3838  { "status_format", DT_STR, R_BOTH, UL &Status, UL "-%r-NeoMutt: %f [Msgs:%?M?%M/?%m%?n? New:%n?%?o? Old:%o?%?d? Del:%d?%?F? Flag:%F?%?t? Tag:%t?%?p? Post:%p?%?b? Inc:%b?%?l? %l?]---(%s/%S)-%>-(%P)---" },
3839  /*
3840  ** .pp
3841  ** Controls the format of the status line displayed in the ``index''
3842  ** menu. This string is similar to $$index_format, but has its own
3843  ** set of \fCprintf(3)\fP-like sequences:
3844  ** .dl
3845  ** .dt %b .dd number of mailboxes with new mail *
3846  ** .dt %d .dd number of deleted messages *
3847  ** .dt %f .dd the full pathname of the current mailbox
3848  ** .dt %F .dd number of flagged messages *
3849  ** .dt %h .dd local hostname
3850  ** .dt %l .dd size (in bytes) of the current mailbox *
3851  ** .dt %L .dd size (in bytes) of the messages shown
3852  ** (i.e., which match the current limit) *
3853  ** .dt %m .dd the number of messages in the mailbox *
3854  ** .dt %M .dd the number of messages shown (i.e., which match the current limit) *
3855  ** .dt %n .dd number of new messages in the mailbox *
3856  ** .dt %o .dd number of old unread messages *
3857  ** .dt %p .dd number of postponed messages *
3858  ** .dt %P .dd percentage of the way through the index
3859  ** .dt %r .dd modified/read-only/won't-write/attach-message indicator,
3860  ** according to $$status_chars
3861  ** .dt %s .dd current sorting mode ($$sort)
3862  ** .dt %S .dd current aux sorting method ($$sort_aux)
3863  ** .dt %t .dd number of tagged messages *
3864  ** .dt %u .dd number of unread messages *
3865  ** .dt %v .dd Mutt version string
3866  ** .dt %V .dd currently active limit pattern, if any *
3867  ** .dt %>X .dd right justify the rest of the string and pad with ``X''
3868  ** .dt %|X .dd pad to the end of the line with ``X''
3869  ** .dt %*X .dd soft-fill with character ``X'' as pad
3870  ** .de
3871  ** .pp
3872  ** For an explanation of ``soft-fill'', see the $$index_format documentation.
3873  ** .pp
3874  ** * = can be optionally printed if nonzero
3875  ** .pp
3876  ** Some of the above sequences can be used to optionally print a string
3877  ** if their value is nonzero. For example, you may only want to see the
3878  ** number of flagged messages if such messages exist, since zero is not
3879  ** particularly meaningful. To optionally print a string based upon one
3880  ** of the above sequences, the following construct is used:
3881  ** .pp
3882  ** \fC%?<sequence_char>?<optional_string>?\fP
3883  ** .pp
3884  ** where \fIsequence_char\fP is a character from the table above, and
3885  ** \fIoptional_string\fP is the string you would like printed if
3886  ** \fIsequence_char\fP is nonzero. \fIoptional_string\fP \fBmay\fP contain
3887  ** other sequences as well as normal text, but you may \fBnot\fP nest
3888  ** optional strings.
3889  ** .pp
3890  ** Here is an example illustrating how to optionally print the number of
3891  ** new messages in a mailbox:
3892  ** .pp
3893  ** \fC%?n?%n new messages.?\fP
3894  ** .pp
3895  ** You can also switch between two strings using the following construct:
3896  ** .pp
3897  ** \fC%?<sequence_char>?<if_string>&<else_string>?\fP
3898  ** .pp
3899  ** If the value of \fIsequence_char\fP is non-zero, \fIif_string\fP will
3900  ** be expanded, otherwise \fIelse_string\fP will be expanded.
3901  ** .pp
3902  ** You can force the result of any \fCprintf(3)\fP-like sequence to be lowercase
3903  ** by prefixing the sequence character with an underscore (``_'') sign.
3904  ** For example, if you want to display the local hostname in lowercase,
3905  ** you would use: ``\fC%_h\fP''.
3906  ** .pp
3907  ** If you prefix the sequence character with a colon (``:'') character, mutt
3908  ** will replace any dots in the expansion by underscores. This might be helpful
3909  ** with IMAP folders that don't like dots in folder names.
3910  */
